People are hyperfocused on 'CO2' and 'global warming'. Running to every high tech solution saying we need to do this without considering the costs and benefit is a bad idea.
We ignore problematic ag practices that increase CO2 through bare earth plowing practices; CAFOs; overgrazing; monocropping; chemical input dependent annual food crops; etc; that directly contribute to flooding, the need for electrical water pumping and brownouts; freshwater shortages; food deserts, reduced nutrition, lack of food diversity, food scarcity; loss of crucial soil biota including mycelium; -aerosolized CO2 and topsoil* loss.
In large areas of the world farmers plow in the Fall and leave bare soil that allows carbon-rich topsoil to be lost to the air. Come late spring they may replant annual crops if conditions are a suitable or leave the soil bare longer still if they aren't. That is a huge contributor to climate warming. In 2017(?) Only 75% of grain crops were planted in the US because conditions were wrong for planting until it was too late.
Conventional organic- and chemical- ag practices indirectly contribute to drought, heat waves, loss of wildlife, flood claims, loss of life, wildfires; loss of resiliency; etc.
('sustainable ag' is a greenwashing term), drought, heat wave, flooding, food deserts, lack of food diversity, poor nutrition, our topsoils are nearly depleted (it's estimated topsoil will be gone in 45 years).

We need solutions that solve for multiple problems. Decentralization reduces costs to taxpayers in infrastructure, maintenance, it bypasses/reduces the need for services, is efficient, creates lower tax burden while building localized resiliency.

Love the approach proposed by climatologist and soil scientist Walter Jehne. It is durable, decentralized and cheap. It uses natural processes that focus on climate cooling through: 1) water sequestration, 2)regreening especially through appropriate trees, and 3) soil health:
1) Due to the loss of soil carbon; as well as the loss of soils; loss of water permeability due to drought, solarization, wind, flooding --means we need to work at rehydrating the land first.
Rainwater harvesting earthworks in drylands and elsewhere add drought, fire, flood mitigation as well as favoring healthier soils. It also recharges aquifers and increases albedo effect, downstream water availability, (the latter seems counterintuitive, but is supported by field studies). It could increase water accessibility for impoverished/isolated/low rainwater communities thru rainwater harvesting via bioswales, curb cuts, using roof runoff, and greywater. These can be used to water food trees grown for nuts, fruit and veggies with safety, as problematic chemicals are deposited in the bark, as well as non edible landscaping and lawns. That's free water. That makes a difference for those that refrain from watering because community water is too expensive. It also reduces grid strain/brownouts because we are now pumping less water this way. It reduces the need for more stormwater infrastructure costs and maintenance, etc. It is durable as well. Swales made in the 1930s by the CCC in the Sonoran desert are still going strong. Look up the video. Ethiopia, India, and Australia have been this as well.
Brad Lancaster is a great resource on rainwater harvesting earthworks in drylands. He has lots of videos and his books give out detailed info. He has worked in both rural and urban areas.
The ideas are scaleable.  It includes curb cuts, swales, bunds, gully repair, check dams, etc.
Geoff Lawton is another good source to see how it works.

2) We can add regreen more land than people realize. People think of the Sahel as a great place for regreening with but we can actually use agricultural land everywhere. Much of cropland and range land is left vulnerable when it can be planted with food producing, longer-lived perennials, shrubs, vines and trees and grasses in polycultures. Appropriate trees produce livestock feed, unusual fruits and vegetables, and even timber. We can do this by planting site-appropriate native trees, shrubs, vines (or plants that are closely related to natives are great for this purpose), etc. Some of the benefits of planting diverse, site-appropriate trees is more food diversity, food security (more food!), fresh fruits, vegetables, nuts, edible leaves, increase food quality (because now you can get fresh food from your bioswale trees), livestock feed, mulch, shade, farm and gardener resilience, timber, transpiration, beauty. They sequester carbon and encourage mycelium and other beneficial organisms for better soil health, heat island reduction, flood mitigation, increased albedo effect, decreased pollution, etc.

3) Healthy soil biota is cheaper than conventional inputs and adds to food production; sequesters carbon; retains moisture; remineralizes; reduces flooding and the need to irrigate; and related labor and material costs and replacement; works without machinery/moving part, etc.

These are part of regenerative/restorative farming and ranching practices that can found under the heading of 'permaculture' when done right. Permaculturists such as Mark Shepard are showing that it can be done on a larger scale and can be profitable. Suggest you read his book Restoration Agriculture first. It explains more on the particulars of his technique. His longer videos also delve into other areas that are eye opening, such as how it is difficult for independent producers to ship via train because the trains are booked up for the next 20 years...
I strongly suggest you watch at least several of Walter Jehne's videos. Each makes different points and explains better the different aspects of why climate works. It's a stunningly simple concept

Other decentralized solutions are: 1) harvesting methane (as it has much more immediate effects on climate than CO²). Methane currently leaks from oil and water wells; septic tanks and wastewater treatment plants; dairy and CAFO manure ponds. A simple bladder system to capture methane for use.
Oil companies are big offenders and are doing little to repair methane leaks from oil wells. We need to harvest it instead. That on Federal land can support vets that are hiding away from society and campgrounds. The leaking oil wells on private land can be used by 'homesteaders' willing to set up in remote places. It could be used for heat, cooking and hot water.
Methane warms the planet on steroids for a decade or two before decaying to CO2. In those short decades, methane warms the planet by 86 times as much as CO2, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.
2) Create and use hydrochar to help restore soils depleted by conventional organic- and chemical- ag practices and the surplus hydrochar could be used for low-hazard fuel. We need wastewater treatment plants anyway. Hydrochar can be cheaper to operate/install than conventional wastewater treatments so this is a good option. Hydrochar can be made after the methane from livestock, manure, sewage solid waste,


The 'centralized' high tech solution that is practical is adding freight and passenger rail in a way similar to Eisenhower's for the interstate highway system. It reduces car dependency. It creates jobs in maintenance, tourism, engineers, creating economic opportunities to ship goods and for otherwise isolated people to travel in underserved communities. It would reduce gridlock, add accessibility resiliency, reduce emissions, This would solve accessibility issues for poor and disabled,
It needs to be methodical and gridded.
The US, Russia, Canada, China, and Australia are wealthy and big polluters and large areas are underserved. Africa, South America and poorer sections of Asia would also benefit as it would connect them to diverse markets and create accessibility.

Beyond these methods I'd be really skeptical unless they had mutifold utility and solve more problems than they create.

Around 2 years ago, on another channel (British), the presenter spoke about a proposed labelling system for food:
Green stickers to be applied to more eco-friendly foods, red ones for the environmentally-costly products.
To this day, I have seen no labelling of this nature introduced in our supermarkets, even though it's a brilliant idea.
Not only does a bright, shiny sticker inform the shopper at a moment's glance, it also has the advantage of publicly shaming those who consistently buy environmentally-burdensome foods.

We really ought to be fast-tracking these sorts of ideas, get them out there to start influencing people in a positive direction.
But, we drag our feet over such innovations (and it seems to me more so in Britain than in most other Western nations). I just wish we'd stop 'talking' about this new labelling system, and get on with applying it.

I think such a labelling systems should go well beyond foods too. We should be naming and shaming a great many other lines of product.

Put those stickers on one-use plastic carrier bags, put them on clothes, and definitely put them on tech products that don't allow users to change what should be simple, readily-exchangeable parts.
For instance: batteries in certain types of recharger.
It's annoying to find the whole thing sealed up, and once it stops recharging properly, the company responsible for its manufacture doesn't want to sell you another recharger if it can help it (usually making it obsolete just a short while before the battery is deliberately manufactured to flatten for good).
No, they want to sell you an entirely new product - so you can imagine how 'tsunamis' of worn out chargers and obsolete products, made popular at one time, suddenly find their way into landfill or get sent off to tech mountains in poorer countries. It's shameful that companies continue to get away with this.

One issue I have with "land usage" counting against animal agriculture is that many times, most times, the land used to graze livestock is not suitable to grow food-crops(Especially fruits and some veggies). Whether that is due to soil conditions, topography affecting the ability of machinery to till, plant and harvest, or climate. Especially here in the US. There is also a lot of work being done with regenerative agriculture- using new pasture management and animal management to improve soil quality and bring back native flora. Animal agriculture can also have a lower impact on local fauna because grazing animals can live among native wildlife and those habitats don't have to be clear cut or destroyed to cultivate crops.

Another point is that a lot of our food waste is "recycled" back into the food chain through animal agriculture- we can feed cows and other animals crop by products (like soybean hulls, cotton seeds, etc). So calories that would have otherwise been wasted are given to animals who turn it into milk and meat. Not to mention, a lot of human food crops are fertilized with manure from animal agriculture. Without that natural fertilizer, crop farmers would have to rely more on synthetic fertilizers.

The parameters of this study seem to really skew the "impact" against animal agriculture- but it is difficult to account for all the nuance. The sectors of agriculture don't exist in a vacuum but I feel like a lot of times those connections are ignored in these kinds of studies.

Another thing to consider on the eco food study: I take it the analysis was for that individual food item and disregards if we can obtain multiple foods (with different nutritional values) throughout the process. Such as how companion crops can improve the overall yields when grown together/rotated, or how some crop byproducts (soy is a common one) can then be up-cycled to also obtain meat.

edit: as a side note, that does not mean meat can magically be much more eco-friendly than plant products. It is still higher up the food chain. It is just a mention that the production itself does not consist of fully isolated bubbles, keeping in mind their interactions can also help in making better choices and changes.
